playn.core

Class AbstractLayer

  • java.lang.Object
    • playn.core.AbstractLayer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Layer
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    LayerCanvas, LayerGL

    public abstract class AbstractLayer
extends Object
implements Layer
    Base Layer implementation shared among platforms (to avoid reinventing the transform logic).

    • Method Detail

      • destroy

        public void destroy()
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Destroys this layer, removing it from its parent layer. Any resources associated with this layer are freed, and it cannot be reused after being destroyed. Destroying a layer that has children will destroy them as well.
        Specified by:
        destroy in interface Layer

      • destroyed

        public boolean destroyed()
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Whether this layer has been destroyed. If true, the layer can no longer be used.
        Specified by:
        destroyed in interface Layer

        Description copied from interface: Layer

      • setVisible

        public Layer setVisible(boolean visible)
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Configures this layer's visibility: if true, it will be rendered as normal, if false it and its children will not be rendered.
        Specified by:
        setVisible in interface Layer
        Returns:
        a reference to this layer for call chaining.

      • interactive

        public boolean interactive()
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Returns true if this layer reacts to clicks and touches. If a layer is interactive, it will respond to Layer.hitTest(pythagoras.f.Point), which forms the basis for the click and touch processing provided by the various addListener methods.
        Specified by:
        interactive in interface Layer

      • setInteractive

        public Layer setInteractive(boolean interactive)
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Configures this layer as reactive to clicks and touches, or not. Note that a layer's interactivity is automatically activated when a listener is added to the layer (or to a child of a GroupLayer) via Layer.addListener(playn.core.Pointer.Listener), etc. Also a GroupLayer will be made non-interactive automatically if an event is dispatched to it and it discovers that it has no interactive children. Manual management of interactivity is thus generally only useful for "leaf" nodes in the scene graph.
        Specified by:
        setInteractive in interface Layer
        Returns:
        a reference to this layer for call chaining.

      • alpha

        public float alpha()
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Return the global alpha value for this layer.

        The global alpha value for a layer controls the opacity of the layer but does not affect the current drawing operation. I.e., when Game.Default.paint(float) is called and the Layer is drawn, this alpha value is applied to the alpha channel of the Layer.

        By default, the alpha for a Layer is 1.0 (not transparent).

        Specified by:
        alpha in interface Layer
        Returns:
        alpha in range [0,1] where 0 is transparent and 1 is opaque

      • setAlpha

        public Layer setAlpha(float alpha)
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Sets the alpha component of this layer's current tint. Note that this value will be quantized to an integer between 0 and 255. Also see Layer.setTint(int).

        Values outside the range [0,1] will be clamped to the range [0,1].

        Specified by:
        setAlpha in interface Layer
        Parameters:
        alpha - alpha value in range [0,1] where 0 is transparent and 1 is opaque.
        Returns:
        a reference to this layer for call chaining.

      • tint

        public int tint()
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Returns the current tint for this layer, as ARGB.
        Specified by:
        tint in interface Layer

      • setTint

        public Layer setTint(int tint)
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Sets the tint for this layer, as ARGB.

        NOTE: this will overwrite any value configured via Layer.setAlpha(float). Either include your desired alpha in the high bits of tint or call Layer.setAlpha(float) after calling this method.

        NOTE: the RGB components of a layer's tint only work on GL-based backends. It is not possible to tint layers using the HTML5 canvas and Flash backends.

        The tint for a layer controls the opacity of the layer but does not affect the current drawing operation. I.e., when Game.Default.paint(float) is called and the Layer is drawn, this tint is applied when rendering the layer.

        Specified by:
        setTint in interface Layer
        Returns:
        a reference to this layer for call chaining.

      • setTx

        public Layer setTx(float x)
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Sets the x translation of this layer.

        Note: all transform changes are deferred until Layer.transform() is called (which happens during rendering, if not before) at which point the current scale, rotation and translation are composed into an affine transform matrix. This means that, for example, setting rotation and then setting scale will not flip the rotation like it would were these applied to the transform matrix one operation at a time.

        Specified by:
        setTx in interface Layer
        Parameters:
        x - translation on x axis
        Returns:
        a reference to this layer for call chaining.

This means that, for example, setting rotation and then setting scale will not flip the rotation like it would were these applied to the transform matrix one operation at a time.

        Specified by:
        setTy in interface Layer
        Parameters:
        y - translation on y axis
        Returns:
        a reference to this layer for call chaining.

      • rotation

        public float rotation()
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Returns this layer's current rotation. Note: this is the most recent value supplied to Layer.setRotation(float), it is not extracted from the underlying transform. Thus the value may lie outside the range [-pi, pi] and the most recently set value is preserved. It's also substantially cheaper than extracting the rotation from the affine transform matrix. This also means that if you change the scale directly on the Layer.transform() that rotation will not be returned by this method.
        Specified by:
        rotation in interface Layer

      • setRotation

        public Layer setRotation(float angle)
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Sets the current rotation of this layer, in radians.

        Note: all transform changes are deferred until Layer.transform() is called (which happens during rendering, if not before) at which point the current scale, rotation and translation are composed into an affine transform matrix. This means that, for example, setting rotation and then setting scale will not flip the rotation like it would were these applied to the transform matrix one operation at a time.

        Specified by:
        setRotation in interface Layer
        Parameters:
        angle - angle to rotate, in radians
        Returns:
        a reference to this layer for call chaining.

      • scaleX

        public float scaleX()
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Returns this layer's current scale in the x direction. Note: this is the most recent value supplied to Layer.setScale(float) or Layer.setScale(float,float), it is not extracted from the underlying transform. Thus the sign of the scale returned by this method is preserved. It's also substantially cheaper than extracting the scale from the affine transform matrix. This also means that if you change the scale directly on the Layer.transform() that scale will not be returned by this method.
        Specified by:
        scaleX in interface Layer

      • scaleY

        public float scaleY()
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Returns this layer's current scale in the y direction. Note: this is the most recent value supplied to Layer.setScale(float) or Layer.setScale(float,float), it is not extracted from the underlying transform. Thus the sign of the scale returned by this method is preserved. It's also substantially cheaper than extracting the scale from the affine transform matrix. This also means that if you change the scale directly on the Layer.transform() that scale will not be returned by this method.
        Specified by:
        scaleY in interface Layer

      • setScale

        public Layer setScale(float s)
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Sets the current x and y scale of this layer to scale.. Note that a scale of 1 is equivalent to no scale.

        Note: all transform changes are deferred until Layer.transform() is called (which happens during rendering, if not before) at which point the current scale, rotation and translation are composed into an affine transform matrix. This means that, for example, setting rotation and then setting scale will not flip the rotation like it would were these applied to the transform matrix one operation at a time.

        Specified by:
        setScale in interface Layer
        Parameters:
        s - non-zero scale value
        Returns:
        a reference to this layer for call chaining.

This means that, for example, setting rotation and then setting scale will not flip the rotation like it would were these applied to the transform matrix one operation at a time.

      • hitTest

        public Layer hitTest(pythagoras.f.Point p)
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Tests whether the supplied (layer relative) point "hits" this layer or any of its children. By default a hit is any point that falls in a layer's bounding box. A group layer checks its children for hits.

        Note that this method mutates the supplied point. If a layer is hit, the point will contain the original point as translated into that layer's coordinate system. If no layer is hit, the point will be changed to an undefined value.

        Specified by:
        hitTest in interface Layer
        Returns:
        this layer if it was the hit layer, a child of this layer if a child of this layer was hit, or null if neither this layer, nor its children were hit.

      • hitTestDefault

        public Layer hitTestDefault(pythagoras.f.Point p)
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Like Layer.hitTest(pythagoras.f.Point) except that it ignores a configured Layer.HitTester. This allows one to configure a hit tester which checks custom properties and then falls back on the default hit testing implementation.
        Specified by:
        hitTestDefault in interface Layer

      • setHitTester

        public Layer setHitTester(Layer.HitTester tester)
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Configures a custom hit tester for this layer. May also be called with null to clear out any custom hit tester.
        Specified by:
        setHitTester in interface Layer
        Returns:
        a reference to this layer for call chaining.

      • transform

        public pythagoras.f.Transform transform()
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Returns the layer's current transformation matrix. If any changes have been made to the layer's scale, rotation or translation, they will be applied to the transform matrix before it is returned.

        Note: any direct modifications to this matrix except modifications to its translation, will be overwritten if a call is subsequently made to Layer.setScale(float), Layer.setScale(float,float), Layer.setScaleX(float), Layer.setScaleY(float) or Layer.setRotation(float). If you intend to manipulate a layer's transform matrix directly, do not call those other methods. Also do not expect Layer.scaleX(), Layer.scaleY(), or Layer.rotation() to reflect the direct changes you've made to the transform matrix. They will not.

        Specified by:
        transform in interface Layer

      • parent

        public GroupLayer parent()
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Returns the parent that contains this layer, or null.
        Specified by:
        parent in interface Layer

      • addListener

        public Connection addListener(Pointer.Listener listener)
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Registers a listener with this layer that will be notified if a click/touch event happens within its bounds. Events dispatched to this listener will have their localX and localY values set to the coordinates of the click/touch as transformed into this layer's coordinate system. x and y will always contain the screen (global) coordinates of the click/touch.

        When a listener is added, the layer and all of its parents are marked as interactive. Interactive layers intercept touches/clicks. When all listeners are disconnected (including Mouse and Touch listeners), the layer will be marked non-interactive. Its parents are lazily marked non-interactive as it is discovered that they have no interactive children. Thus if you require that a layer continue to intercept click/touch events to prevent them from being dispatched to layers "below" it, you must register a NOOP listener on the layer, or manually call Layer.setInteractive(boolean) after removing the last listener.

        Specified by:
        addListener in interface Layer

      • addListener

        public Connection addListener(Mouse.LayerListener listener)
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Registers a listener with this layer that will be notified if a mouse event happens within its bounds. Events dispatched to this listener will have their localX and localY values set to the coordinates of the mouse as transformed into this layer's coordinate system. x and y will always contain the screen (global) coordinates of the mouse.

        When a listener is added, the layer and all of its parents are marked as interactive. Interactive layers intercept mice events. When all listeners are disconnected (including Pointer and Touch listeners), the layer will be marked non-interactive. Its parents are lazily marked non-interactive as it is discovered that they have no interactive children. Thus if you require that a layer continue to intercept mouse events to prevent them from being dispatched to layers "below" it, you must register a NOOP listener on the layer, or manually call Layer.setInteractive(boolean) after removing the last listener.

        Specified by:
        addListener in interface Layer

      • addListener

        public Connection addListener(Touch.LayerListener listener)
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Registers a listener with this layer that will be notified if a touch event happens within its bounds. Events dispatched to this listener will have their localX and localY values set to the coordinates of the touch as transformed into this layer's coordinate system. x and y will always contain the screen (global) coordinates of the touch.

        When a listener is added, the layer and all of its parents are marked as interactive. Interactive layers intercept touches/clicks. When all listeners are disconnected (including Mouse and Touch listeners), the layer will be marked non-interactive. Its parents are lazily marked non-interactive as it is discovered that they have no interactive children. Thus if you require that a layer continue to intercept click/touch events to prevent them from being dispatched to layers "below" it, you must register a NOOP listener on the layer, or manually call Layer.setInteractive(boolean) after removing the last listener.

        Specified by:
        addListener in interface Layer

      • setShader

        public Layer setShader(GLShader shader)
        Description copied from interface: Layer
        Configures a custom shader for use when rendering this layer (and its children). Passing null will cause the default shader to be used. Configuring a shader on a group layer will cause that shader to be used when rendering the group layer's children, unless the child has a custom shader configured itself.
        Specified by:
        setShader in interface Layer
        Returns:
        a reference to this layer for call chaining.
